review_title: Great as a brand - But they should be more thorough when hiring Management.
pros: Great perks with company discount on products, pay continuity during the COVID 19 pandemic, the brand itself is really inspiring to work for.
cons:
With the company being so large and so many movements happening all the time, there can be negatively impactful changes such a management that is thrown into a role without being qualified and maybe not the best fit for a people management role solely based on Nike being desperate to fill the role. I've watched this result in the morale of an entire team plummet and losing more than half the staff within a month because of lack of good management, empathy or care. This isn't great for the company as it resulted in them losing quality employees that were hard working and passionate that Nike had invested lots of time and money into. When there is high amount of turnover in a team in a short amount of time, HR should investigate as to why this might of happened and how it could of been prevented.

Management has a lot of control over the careers of those below them, to the point of controlling whether someone is even allowed to apply for a role - so it should be taken very seriously as to who Nike chooses to fill these leadership roles.

review_title: Clever transfer of wealth from contractors to permanent employees
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: Lots of good managers, good career opportunities if you are aggressive enough in owning your career, chance to work with cutting edge technologies alongside some of the smartest engineers, decent benefits, access to many facilities on campus.
cons: Nike recently announced that employees will receive paid days off for 5 days in July and 5 days in August. On the surface, this sounds like the company really cares about employee well-being by offering essentially additional PTO. That is until you realize that half of those employed within corporate are contractors that are not eligible for this "benefit" and are forced to take an unpaid day off, so they are basically getting a 20% reduction in pay for the summer (with no option to make up those hours even if they wanted to). The company has basically found a clever way to transfer 8 hours of pay to permanent employees by taking away those 8 hours of pay from their contractor counterparts.

pros:
• Work/Life balance (less competitive salary reflects this)
• Movement within the company
cons:
• Many folks have worked decades at Nike and have lost their competitive knowledge edge. 
• I walked in passionate and will be leaving the company depleted.  There’s not a lot to learn here, top heavy, over-complicated “matrix.”
• Forced relocation can be hard if you’re moving from a big city.  Portland is small and even smaller with the volume of Nike employees everywhere. 

Overall if you want to feel comfortable and your life priority is work/life balance at a less competitive salary, this is the place for you!  If you are ambitious and want to learn, grow and push yourself to do new innovate things and be around others who have that same drive, you’ll easily lose who you are and feel disappointed.

pros: Genuinely I would say the discounts and perks you have are a great pro. Nike stretches your perks to your family(immediate family)as well which is a great thing to have. Another pro would be if you don’t have a lot of experience this would be something great to get your foot in the door since most starting jobs pay 7.25 per hour. Last but not least another pro would be the amount of support you have from outside workers, you have people who will assist you with your resume if you need that, you have people with Nike that can assist you with how to manage your money and also it’s a networking hub which I felt was the best pro to me.
cons: I would say the lack of communication sometimes with management can get a little dicey. To elaborate on that our particular store had a lot of management changes going on and at times it would be confusing on who exactly you needed to answer to. Secondly I would say there were situations where I would notice certain co workers talking about and singling out others behind their backs which was pretty sad to see since they were the “leads” on the floor. Thirdly but a branch off of the second the management may or may not have talked about other workers behind their backs but they’ve definitely had their favorites within the workplace and catered to them more when it came with hours and how they handled things face to face.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in Beaverton, OR
pros: Nike's business is strong and continues to grow. The campus in Oregon is beautiful and full of great amenities. There is a large technology organization, and some teams are building interesting solutions to solve very large scale problems. You get to see and attend events with sponsored athletes on campus. Summer Hours are nice, where the office closes at noon on Fridays. Pay is competitive for some technology professionals, but pay is not always equitable across the org.
cons:
Nike has been undergoing a reorg for over a year, and the roll out of those changes in Global Technology has been delayed again and again. Good engineers are leaving the company. There is a cloud of uncertainty due to the reorg, and many leaders won't make any decisions until it is done.

New CDIO is pushing rapidly to outsource IT to his favorite vendors and send work to India and Poland. I don't think this will go well for Nike, which traditionally has been a face-to-face meeting company. It doesn't always write down requirements, so getting engineers across the world to do this work could go slower or cause quality issues.

Promotions basically have been stalled for years. Backfills take forever to get approved, and even then sometimes they are denied or taken away from teams.

pros:
*Team-Based Work Style: feels more like working with teammates than co-workers. Managers feel like coaches. Looser, more relaxed way of communication. 
*Discounts: Many people work in the retail sector at Nike Chicago for the numerous benefits it has to offer. A robust discount, access to employee-only raffles, opportunities to see and purchase product on day of release - this benefit is however subject to a great amount of abuse, as I've witnessed employees hide/steal product for their own gain. (See Cons)
cons:
*Abusing Benefits: I frequently witnessed coworkers hiding "high-heat" products in backrooms for them to purchase at conclusion of shift. Many employees also were able to purchase product directly from "Hash" (returned or exchanged products that are meant to be mailed directly to another store), even though we were explicitly told that product in Hash could not be purchased by employees or customers. This part of the business seemed to operate on favoritism-if you were liked by certain members of the store, you were allowed to purchase from Hash. Employee raffles were also held frequently to give us the chance to win exclusive shoes, however, the raffles were always won by the same people. (I worked at the store for seven months and never won a single raffle; I witnessed others win at least 3 times in the course of one month). When a handful of people were caught for hiding "high-heat" product in the store for purchase later, none were reprimanded or terminated (they all worked at the store for at least 3 years). These people were generally favorited by others because they were "good" at their job. (In order to thrive at Nike Chicago, you have to be loud, obnoxious, and annoying. Leave any sense of professionalism at the door). If you don't have the energy of an NBA mascot, you aren't going to do very well. 
*Many employees, from management to coworkers, were very rude. I was astounded by the attitude some coworkers had, even upper management. Behavior that certainly wouldn't fly at another retailer.
*Management is largely incompetent, for most of them, this is the only place they have really held a real job at, they are inexperienced in the world of business and communication. Because of that, management is largely mediocre, hard to communicate with, unreliable, and clique-y. 
*Like I said before, if you are serious about working here, leave any sense of professionalism at the door. They mistake professionalism for a lack of energy and interest. If you are really good at annoying people, or being a loudmouth, you will move up the ranks at this store very quickly. If you also like assaulting customers with asinine "would-you-rather" questions instead of asking them business-relevant questions, you will be offered a promotion within a few months. The whole store is conducted like a varsity basketball team - if you aren't a star player, you're on the bench.

pros:
- Work/life balance,

- PM and PO are often people with no product experience (mostly coming from business) and no long term product vision

- leadership likes to use big words like AI and ML in presentations but there is no short or long term plans. It’s just a red herring

- promotions are mostly based on tenure and knowing the right people

- surprisingly not that international. Most leaders (directors and up) are Dutch and many product teams are fully Indian or Dutch. 

- the analytics org is a mess. In 2 years at least 2 big changes have happened and still not all analytics teams belong to the same family. Good luck if you are in the wrong team!

review_title: Excellent Culture, Quality Work, Good Work-life balance
pros:
Nike started their Development Center in India in second half of 2020. You will be joining a fairly new team. You might even get to set up a new team and watch it grow.

Infrastructure: Nike has partnered with the organisations that has the best product in the domain( AWS, Atlassian, Splunk etc). You get to work on some of the best tools you could hope for. You would be spending quality time designing and developing things.

Work: You could be working on Tier0 services which powers a core functionality, which gives you a lot of chances to work with Senior Engineers and learn from people who has immense knowledge of the domain. People are usually very approachable in Nike.

Work-Life-Balance : Nike takes good care of its employees. For instance, all the employees were given a weeks off in the Month of August for 'destress'. Good leave policy too.
cons: Nothing specific. Even if you find any, the leadership takes the feedback in a constructive way. You can bring the change!

review_title: Please read if you even consider working for Nike!!!
pros: Amazing opportunities for personal growth and learning and there is a reason why Nike leads the market, which is a huge innovation and technology investment and the strategy of working years ahead of the game, which leads and inspire the market.
cons: Nike doesn't care about people and they face an Immature leadership overall and some people on managing roles should never be leading or managing anyone. You will see people from other countries that only had experience in Factory fields with absolutely non soft skills and still doing the: - Do my way or hit the highway!! Also, don't forget that you always be on the stress of: Here comes another "Re-Alignment" and Am I going to lose my job or not?? They will preach you about Networking, which means "Brown Nosing", so if you want to grow You must be able to manage the political BS. They will promise you promotions which may never happen and they will keep bringing new skills that you have to develop before getting to your next level, so they try to make you feel that you are never ready. The HR department overall is a joke and you can't trust them, they will preach you about the Non-Retaliation Policy or: If you see something, say something!! but if you say something and you face a situation, the company will take the opportunity in the next "Re-Alignment" to get rid of you once they don't want any type of conflicts and this is all about the business, so the part that is more relevant to them or has more to offer will always win, no matter what the case is, and if you face that, the same HR person that told you that was there for you and would help you, will be the one setting up your meeting when you get let go, so DON"T trust HR. Despite that, there is a hands full of great leaders and I would NOT certainly include the new CEO - John D on this list, the only thing He cares is about himself, but what I can tell you is: YES, THERE IS LIFE OUTSIDE NIKE!!! and great opportunities out there, so if you ever decide to work for this company, make sure to take the advantage of learning as much as you can and always keep in mind that you are a passenger on this company and the end of your trip could be at anytime, so if that happens, you will be prepared and remember and memorize this saying: YOU ARE JUST A NUMBER!!!! NIKE DOESN'T CARE ABOUT YOU!!!!THIS IS ALL ABOUT THE BUSINESS!!!!

HR's only objective is to avoid a lawsuit. Be careful who you trust, this is very much a gentleman club. They will use you as much as they can and fire afterwards in a 3 min zoom call. Do not expect any opportunities, Black and Brown women do not make it to the top, EVER. People frequently sleep their way to positions.

job_title: Part Time Athlete in Barstow, CA
pros:
All employees generally had positive attitudes and were committed to working as a team. Most managers were willing to assist in any tasks that needed to be done.

The online discount is nice if you want to buy newer items. The in store discount is also great. It's best however to just wait until staff dress time to use the elevated discount.
cons:
Instead of offering full time positions to experienced employees, the company instead hires tons or seasonals year-round that constantly need training, only to leave a few months later. The part time employees will end up working less hours than seasonals, which creates poor communication between different areas of the store.

During covid Nike decided to not offer any yearly raises to employees. When stores reopened, part time workers often were scheduled 40 hour weeks but were left out of any full time employee benefits.

After covid, it was nearly impossible for our store to get enough cleaning supplies to properly sanitize the store under the guidelines we were given

Advancing in the company is extremely difficult. You're expected to work months or even years in "stretch" manager roles without getting paid for it to hopefully one day get an official promotion.

review_title: If you enjoy being treated like a slave...
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Beaverton, OR
pros: The pay was "alright". That's about the only pro. I guess the surrounding landscape was nice also.
cons:
1. Nike is TOTALLY unwilling to compromise with your schedule, even by as little as 30 minutes. In my case, I worked a ton of overtime without any additional pay, that wasn't considered. You are an economic unit to Nike and screw any needs from your personal life.

2. If you're right-wing, this is NOT the place to be. You will be bullied for your beliefs. Not only that, but in my case, the agile coach explicitly attempted to sabotage my position; If it weren't for my stellar performance, their plan likely would have succeeded.

3. Zero perks for working there. I've worked at small, medium and large companies; Nike is one of the few places where you will still need to pay for snacks and drinks there.

job_title: Retail Brand Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: From my experience working for large Corp is never perfect and hoping for that is naive. Working for Nike has moments where you feel a part of a big family and the truth is, they are the leaders for a reason. Being a part of Nike, employees will gain invaluable experience at all levels in most functions.
cons:
Reorganization happens too often, middle and lower management is completely discombobulated, communication around it is terrible. 

Nike needs to look at their sustainability. Retail needs to be less wasteful, POP and retail executions continue to be massively wasteful (most marketing materials ending in landfill )

Their compensation is good, their senior leadership has the scales tipped, they should find a way to ensure all employees make a living wage for the geography they live, this includes compensation for commuting.

Work/Life balance, there is a unwritten rule that you need to give blood, sweat and tears to be successful there.

review_title: Amazing brand, culture, colleagues and leadership. Worst HR and organizational structure.
pros:
Diverse and Inclusive culture. 
Colleagues are very collaborative and supportive, and professional at the same time. Many will become your best friends.
Brand loyalty is a must.
Processes are transparent and most leadership is very open and transparent about company's strategy and decision making.
Data driven decision making is emphasized.
cons:
HR policies lack transparency at higher levels. Rules of transparent hiring apply only to analyst and manager level, and do not apply to Sr. Director and above level.
Internal promotion is extremely difficult. You have to basically apply and interview, just as an external candidate. You cannot contact the hiring manager about the role if you work with him/her/they directly on everyday basis. After you apply, HR and recruiters won't reply for months and won't reply at all. No respect for internal candidates or experience by HR, hence moving up the ladder is extremely difficult. 
If you know someone higher up, you can become a Sr. Director or VP directly from being an analyst or manager with little experience, you don't need to interview or apply.
Low turnover up to Manager level. Extremely high turnover above Director level, resulting into continuous strategy changes.
